result.title: Feasibility study on SIT-based approaches for management of key pests
result.description: Description: Report on the feasibility of SIT-like approaches for control of key pests of tomato, grape and leafy vegetables (e.g. Tuta absoluta, Lobesia botrana and Delia radicum), notably potential for laboratory mass rearing, knowledge required on field biology, compatibility of current/future IPM methods and economic justifiability.

result.title: Increased efficiency of micro BCAs against Botrytis through entomovectoring in tomatoes and grapes
result.description: Description: The potential of the entomovectoring of a selection of micro BCAs with use of bumblebees (Bombus terrestris) against grey mould Botrytis cinerea in tomatoes in greenhouses will be tested. A bumblebee-specific dispenser as developed by the UGENT-partner can be used (Mommaerts et al., 2010). This dispenser will be filled with formulated micro BCA. We will use a setup with randomized blind blocks as published before in Mommaerts et al. (2012). A similar setup will be used for micro BCAs in grapes in open field. Here we plan to use hives of honeybees (Apis mellifera) and a specific honeybee-dispenser that can be attached to a commercial honeybee hive and that is available in the market (Smagghe et al., 2012).

result.title: New micro and macro BCAs and botanical pesticides against key pests in tomatoes, leafy vegetables and grapes
result.description: Pest management methods relying on the use of botanical insecticides and newly developed micro and macro BCAs; all methods will meet requirements for being use in organic farming cropping systems (e.g. on tomato and leafy vegetables)

result.title: Potential for RNAi as a pest control strategy
result.description: Description: The potential for RNAi as a pest control strategy against moths (notably Tuta absoluta and Lobesia botrana) and whiteflies (Bemisia tabaci) will be assessed. Target genes will be selected based on selectivity and efficacy and optimal doses and concentrations will be determined. Additionally, an optimisation of the delivery method and formulation will be carried out based on what is already known from literature

result.title: Paternal Effect Lethality based SIT against P. xylostella
result.description: Description: the Paternal Effect Lethality (PEL) phenotype – repressible male ‘sterility’ - will be developed and proven in P. xylostella, with a view to combining with female-lethality (previously developed).
